Comment: This was a standard game between two low-ranked players.
An unusual (and doubtful) move. The only threat is Qxe4, which I easily blocked.

Another eclectic move, which opens up no more space for black. If it was meant in a long-term defensive way, guarding against a push through the centre at d5, why play the queen so strangely?
This, of course, allows Qxf2#. I had prepared Be3 as a response to Bc5, but forgot to play it! I would deserved to lose here, but luckily for me black missed the opportunity.

My intention was to continue 8... bxa4 9 Nxa4, attacking c5 and preserving good development. At all costs I wanted to prevent 8... a4, trapping my bishop.
A clever move, keeping up pressure on white's queen-side and forcing the knight to retreat.
Black's pawn storm was pushing me further and further back. I chose this moment to blunt his advance without sacrificing material.
